awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How online foci shape conversation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the characteristics of online communities that shape the quality of their conversations.  Social media sites are not homogeneous; they are made up of online “foci” of interaction -- online communities like groups, blogs, and discussion forums characterized by their stability and bounded nature. In certain foci, conversations are friendly and constructive, in others, hostile and unproductive. The goal of this study is to understand how the different characteristics of online foci — their cultures, moderation policies, attitudes towards outsiders, and social relationships — influence the quality of their conversations. Findings will advance scientific knowledge to improve a democratic society and help scholars and practitioners imagine and design a more inclusive and democratic online public sphere.

This study leverages a large-scale multilevel dataset that covers all public conversations that unfolded during a major campaign across 1,058 topical forums on a popular platform. The data consist of 1.2 billion comments, 8.2 billion reactions to posts, and 2.6 billion reactions to comments among three hundred million users across 7.5 million posts.  In addition, the project collects labeled comments to train machine learning models that measure and predict whether comments are deliberative according to two core dimensions: the civility of conversations and meaningful cross-ideological interactions. These data, in conjunction with recent methodological advances in the analysis of quasi-experimental designs, social network analysis, natural language processing, and multilevel modeling strategies, are used to identify the characteristics of online foci that foster cross-ideological interaction and civil discourse and to understand the role online foci play in moderating the impact of divisive, exogenous social events.  This project is supported jointly by the Sociology, Methodology, Measurement, and Statistics, Human Networks and Data Science-Research, and Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace Programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past few decades, political polarization has intensified within American society, deepening ideological divides and threatening the foundations of deliberative democracy. Scholars are divided on the role of social media in this process. Some argue that it exacerbates polarization by replacing face-to-face dialogue with more insulated online interactions, while others contend that it can foster political deliberation by exposing individuals to diverse viewpoints. Our research aims to investigate the potential for productive and civil cross-ideological interactions in both online and offline spaces and to develop methodological tools for analyzing relational and text data to capture these interactions.

Our project has yielded several significant insights. First, we observed a notable decline in cross-ideological interactions when social interactions moved predominantly online due to pandemic-related social distancing. This supports the hypothesis that online environments tend to increase polarization compared to offline settings. Second, an analysis of comment threads in public forums revealed that approximately one-quarter of online discourse was productive, while another quarter was deemed toxic or highly toxic. This underscores both the potential and limitations of online platforms for deliberation. Third, we identified substantial partisan differences in how users interpret the productivity and toxicity of online conversations, particularly on contentious issues such as gun control and abortion. These differences point toward challenges in creating mutual agreement across ideological camps in polarized environments. Fourth, our findings show that liberals and conservatives employ distinct language patterns when discussing political topics, particularly during periods of heightened political tension, such as elections. This gap persists even in non-political discussions, suggesting that ideological signaling is pervasive on social media. Finally, cross-ideological interactions tend to amplify ideological cues in language use, which often leads to increased toxicity in conversations. Notably, the same users change how they communicate depending on the context, signaling greater polarization in more ideologically mixed settings. Collectively, these findings point to multiple sources of polarization and highlight both the promises and pitfalls of social media as a space for public deliberation.

This project was also instrumental in establishing the Networks in Context Lab, a new interdisciplinary research group that spans institutions across the U.S., including NYU, Cornell, Stanford, Columbia, Indiana, UCLA, and the University of Chicago. The lab brings together scholars from sociology, computer science, data science, and information science to study social interactions in real-time and understand how they are influenced by broader social phenomena such as political polarization, segregation, and inequality. The project also provided extensive training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students. Several doctoral students used data collected from this project as part of their dissertation research, and many students developed skills in data management and analysis. Finally, this project developed methodological toolkits for analyzing social interaction and discourses using network approaches and large language models. These tools will aid researchers and practitioners in evaluating the quality of online and offline interactions, ultimately contributing to the creation of a more inclusive and democratic public sphere.
